title: Newtons second law - normal forces in elevator

content.question: A <math alttext="60 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math> person is riding in an elevator. At time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the elevator is accelerating downward with a magnitude of <math alttext="2 meters per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mtext>m/s</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. A short time later, at time <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, the elevator is accelerating upward with a magnitude of <math alttext="2 meters per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mtext>m/s</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. The ratio of the normal force exerted by the elevator on the person at time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> to that at time <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is most nearly

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
